metadata.case_name: Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Bhaiyalal Shukla was doing business as contractor for construction of buildings, roads, bridges etc., as contractor for the Public Works Department in Rewa Circle of the former Vindhya Pradesh State, now part of the State of Madhya Pradesh.

Six petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution filed by Bhaiyalal Shukla challenging levy of sales tax on building materials supplied by him in construction of buildings, roads and bridges for years 1953-54 to 1958-59.
For 1953-54, sales tax amounting to Rs. 1,840-5-0 charged and paid; seeks refund.
For remaining years except last two, proceedings for assessment completed but amounts not paid.
For last two years, proceedings pending for assessment of tax.
Respondents: State of Madhya Pradesh (substituted for Vindhya Pradesh) and officers connected with assessment and levy.
United State of Vindhya Pradesh formed by Rulers of Baghelkhand and Bundelkhand with Maharaja of Rewa as Rajpramukh.
Covenant provided legislative authority vested in Rajpramukh to make Ordinances having force of Act.
Rajpramukh promulgated Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949 for levy of tax on sale of goods.
On inauguration of Constitution, Vindhya Pradesh became Part B State, later Part C by Constitution Amendment Order 1950.
Ordinance applied to whole Vindhya Pradesh from April 1, 1950 by Notification No. 7 of March 28, 1950 by Chief Commissioner under s. 1(2) of Ordinance.

Parliament passed Part C States Laws Act, 1950; s.2 empowered Central Govt to extend enactments from Part A States to Part C States with modifications, including repeal/amendment of corresponding laws.

Central Govt by Notification S.R.O. 6 dated December 29, 1950 extended Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (as in force in MP) to Vindhya Pradesh with modifications; added s.29 repealing Ordinance 2 of 1949 with savings.
On March 20, 1951, Notification No. 52/ECON brought extended Act into force from April 1, 1951 in Vindhya Pradesh.
Supreme Court in Delhi Laws Act case (1951 SCR 747) held s.2 Part C States Laws Act intra vires except concluding sentence on repeal/amendment.
Parliament passed Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951) setting up Legislative Assemblies with powers under State/Concurrent Lists subject to parliamentary override (s.22).
Part C States Miscellaneous Laws Repealing Act, 1951 (66 of 1951) repealed Ordinance 2 of 1949 from December 29, 1950.

Vindhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly passed Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act, 1952 (6 of 1952) effective January 8, 1953 declaring CP & Berar Sales Tax Act deemed in force from April 1, 1951; repealed corresponding prior laws with savings.
CP & Berar Sales Tax Act s.2 defined contract, goods, sale to include materials in execution of works contracts for buildings, roads, bridges etc., making them taxable.
Vindhya Pradesh Act 9 of 1953 amended the extended Act with verbal changes but not altering tax structure.
After States Reorganisation, Madhya Pradesh has multiple sales tax laws from different regions continuing under s.119 States Reorganisation Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether sales tax is leviable on building materials supplied in execution of works contracts under the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 as extended to Vindhya Pradesh, given decisions in Gannon Dunkerley, Banarsidas and Mithan Lal cases.
Whether the extension of the Act to Vindhya Pradesh was validly done by Parliament/Central Govt or by State Legislature, affecting its competence to tax works contract materials.
Whether differential application of sales tax laws in different parts of Madhya Pradesh post-reorganisation violates Art. 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tax not leviable on building materials in works contracts in view of State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley (1959 SCR 379) and Pandit Banarsidas v. State of MP (1959 SCR 427).

Notification S.R.O. 6 invalid in repealing Ordinance due to Delhi Laws Act case; no sales tax law till Vindhya Pradesh Validating Act 1952 which extended Act as State law, incompetent per Gannon Dunkerley.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Laws Act 1951 SCR 747; Gannon Dunkerley 1959 SCR 379

petitioner_arguments.text: Validating Act 1952 and Amendment Act 1953 re-enacted/extended the Act as State law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Deepchand v. State of UP 1959 Supp 2 SCR 8

petitioner_arguments.text: Post-reorganisation, unequal tax liability in MP violates Art. 14.

respondent_arguments.text: Tax leviable as case falls within Mithan Lal v. State of Delhi (1959 SCR 445); extension by Parliament under Part C States Laws Act valid despite Gannon Dunkerley.
Notifications and Repealing Act 1951, Validating Act 1952 concurred in repealing Ordinance from Dec 29 1950 and keeping extended Act intact; Validating Act merely removed doubts, did not re-enact.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Part C States Laws Act 1950; Part C States Misc Laws Repealing Act 1951

court_reasoning.text: Act validly extended by Central Govt under Part C States Laws Act 1950 (SRO 6); Parliament via Repealing Act 1951 cured defect in repeal of Ordinance from Dec 29 1950; not invalidated by Delhi Laws Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parliamentary legislation rescued the Notification by repealing Ordinance.

court_reasoning.text: Deepchand case inapplicable; extended law did not depend on prior repeal for validity; Repealing Act made Ordinance deemed repealed from Dec 29 1950.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If cause of unconstitutionality removed, no need for re-enactment.

court_reasoning.text: Validating Act 1952 did not re-extend or enact the Act; merely declared it deemed in force from Apr 1 1951 to remove doubts; s.7 repealed prior laws like Ordinance, not the extension.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Powers circumscribed by s.22 Govt of Part C States Act; could not repeal parliamentary extension.

court_reasoning.text: Act valid per Mithan Lal as parliamentary extension, not subject to Gannon Dunkerley limits on State legislatures.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parliament had plenary powers for Part C States.

court_reasoning.text: Post-reorganisation differences valid under s.119 States Reorg Act; geographical classification based on history upheld.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 14 not violated; similar to Gwalior Sugar case.

holdings.text: Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 validly extended to Vindhya Pradesh by Parliament/Central Govt; sales tax on building materials in works contracts leviable.
Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act 1952 did not re-enact or freshly extend the Act; merely validated prior extension.
No violation of Art. 14 in differential sales tax application post-reorganisation.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No State power to tax sales of materials in entire works contracts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Banarsidas v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate contracts for materials taxable, but entire works contracts not.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mithan Lal v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Parliamentary extension to Part C States valid despite State limitations.
Part of s.2 Part C States Laws Act ultra vires for repeal power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deepchand v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Validity tested at enactment; after-acquired power does not validate without re-enactment (inapplicable here).

precedents_cited.case_name: Gannon Dunkerley v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved view that no sale in works contracts.

precedents_cited.case_name: M.K. Prithvi Rajji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Geographical classification on historical reasons valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Gwalior Sugar Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Differential cess in regions upheld under Art. 14.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under Art.32; Parliament's residuary tax powers; equal protection.

statutes_cited.name: Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior law repealed; applied from Apr 1 1950.

statutes_cited.name: Part C States Laws Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to extend Part A laws to Part C States.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (21 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Act taxing works contract materials.

statutes_cited.name: Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Part C legislatures' powers subject to Parliament.

Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act, 1952 (6 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Declared Act in force from Apr 1 1951; repealed prior laws.

outcome.summary: The petitions challenging the levy of sales tax on building materials in works contracts are dismissed; the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 as extended to Vindhya Pradesh is held valid and operative from April 1, 1951, upholding the tax.

key_quotes.text: "Parliamentary legislation, therefore came to the rescue, so to speak, of the Notification by making room for the extension of the Central Provinces and Berar Act by repealing Ordinance 2 of 1949."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains how Repealing Act cured Notification defect.

key_quotes.text: "The validity of a statute is to be tested by the constitutional power of a legislature at the time of its enactment... An after acquired power cannot, ex proprio vigore, validate a statute void when enacted."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "whatever might be said of the State Legislatures operating under List II did not hold good in the case of Parliament which derived its powers... from the residuary powers of taxation mentioned in Art. 248(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Mithan Lal; justifies plenary power.
